Despite being intimidating, Japanese is not that hard as one may think! It’s a highly analytical language, as: Japanese nouns have no genders, plural forms, or accompanying articles to learn.The language also has only two verb tenses, present and past, and includes very few irregular verbs.Spoken Japanese has only 5 vowel sounds and spelling is phonetically consistent, making the language relatively easy to pronounce.The Grammar of Japanese is very similar to that of Korean. Both languages have an equally advanced system of honorifics for showing respect.Japanese takes its Kanji writing system from the Chinese system of ideographs.Learning Japanese brings you a step closer to taking on Korean or Chinese because of the above two reasons.  There are four different writing systems of Japanese: Rōmaji, which is simply the latin representation of Japanese. ( As illustrated earlier: kon’nichiwa or hello)Hiragana is the Japanese alphabet. All words can be written in it. 3. Kanji characters are originally from China. China uses only Kanji (and is called Hanzi)   4. Katakana is used to write foreign, 'borrowed' words in Japanese. Eg : Taxi (English) : タクシー (Katakana) and Takushī (Romanji) - sounds similar, but pronounced (kinda) differently due to English & Japanese separate accents.  Eg: Japan in english, Nihon in rōmaji; Hiragana: にほん ; Kanji: 日本 ; Or say:  Hiragana was created from Kanji to write some letters faster than writing with only Kanji. Combining all of them in a sentence will then will you realize or easily define some signs and read even faster.  Traditionally, Japanese is written in a format called tategaki, which is inspired by the traditional Chinese system. In this format, the characters are written in columns going from top to bottom, with columns ordered from right to left. After reaching the bottom of each column, the reader continues at the top of the column to the left of the current one. 2. Modern Japanese also uses another writing format, called yokogaki. This writing format is horizontal and reads from left to right, as in English.
